claim: All of Snow White's dwarfs can play a game of 7 Wonders simultaneously.

supporting.text: Snow White's dwarfs are traditionally depicted as seven individuals, making it impossible for them to play a game designed for seven players without excluding someone.

attacks.text: Snow White's dwarfs are traditionally depicted as seven individuals, making it impossible for them to play a game designed for seven players without excluding someone.
The game 7 Wonders allows for fewer than seven players by adjusting the rules or using variants, so the dwarfs could still play together.
Even with rule adjustments, the game experience is optimized for exactly seven players, making the dwarfs' gameplay suboptimal or incomplete.
Snow White could join the game as an eighth participant, allowing all seven dwarfs to play without exclusion.
The claim specifies 'Snow White's dwarfs,' implying only the seven dwarfs are involved, excluding Snow White from the game.
Some versions of the Snow White story feature more or fewer than seven dwarfs, potentially invalidating the original argument.
The traditional and most widely recognized depiction of Snow White's dwarfs is exactly seven, making edge-case versions irrelevant to the claim.

supporting.text: The game 7 Wonders requires each player to have their own set of cards and resources, which would necessitate seven distinct participants, matching the number of dwarfs exactly.

attacks.text: The game 7 Wonders requires each player to have their own set of cards and resources, which would necessitate seven distinct participants, matching the number of dwarfs exactly.
Not all dwarfs may be willing or able to participate in the game due to personal preferences or physical limitations.
The dwarfs are known to work and play together harmoniously, making it likely they would all participate if the game was proposed.
The game setup might require more space or resources than the dwarfs' living quarters can accommodate.
The dwarfs' home is depicted as spacious enough to host all of them comfortably, suggesting it could accommodate a game setup.

supporting.text: If all seven dwarfs are playing, there would be no one left to observe or facilitate the game, which is impractical for gameplay dynamics.

attacks.text: If all seven dwarfs are playing, there would be no one left to observe or facilitate the game, which is impractical for gameplay dynamics.
The game 7 Wonders is designed for exactly seven players, so all dwarfs can participate without needing an observer or facilitator.
Even if the game is designed for seven players, some games benefit from an impartial observer or facilitator to ensure rules are followed.
The dwarfs are known to be cooperative and rule-abiding, reducing the need for an external facilitator.

supporting.text: The narrative roles of the dwarfs (e.g., mining, chores) suggest they are not all available simultaneously for leisure activities like playing a full game of 7 Wonders.

attacks.text: The narrative roles of the dwarfs (e.g., mining, chores) suggest they are not all available simultaneously for leisure activities like playing a full game of 7 Wonders.
The dwarfs are often depicted together in scenes, implying they do have shared leisure time despite their individual roles.
Shared scenes do not necessarily indicate simultaneous availability for a lengthy game, as their interactions are often brief or task-oriented.
7 Wonders is a relatively short game (30-45 minutes), which could feasibly fit into their schedule during breaks or after work.
The dwarfs' work is physically demanding, making extended leisure activities like board games unlikely after a long day of mining.
